author: nishant0
content: I think the attnets revamp will help a lot in general, at the cost of increasing bandwidth consumption for the average node across the network. I agree with mikhail, that in general I would be a lot more worried about computational complexity of the continued increase in the validator set size. At 2 million keys you run into a lot of memory and CPU constraints with regards to general block processing and more importantly epoch processing, what worked at 100 - 200k , might not be feasible with 2 million

author: arnetheduck
content:
I believe concerns the aggregation performance may have been the result implementation detail in prysm specifically - creating and disseminating aggregates is relatively cheap because of the structure of the network (ie aggregating singles is straightforward and cheap - there's also no packing or other np-complete stuff to do) - however, decompressing and validating signatures on _anything_ is expensive and here it's a numbers game: more signatures = more cost, more or less. and attestations _by far_ make up the largest amount of signatures per slot.

this pattern repeats because as <@425572898787426305> points out, the cost of an attestation is multiplied by having to send it to many connections, each of which is individually encrypted - aggregates are relatively cheap here, specially since https://github.com/ethereum/consensus-specs/pull/2847 because we don't forward non-contributing aggregates so there are not so many to validate

author: arnetheduck
content: with regards to epoch processing, I share this concern - there are several quadratic operations in the spec that clients optimise down to linear more or less with caches/memoization, but they tend to be linear, but they're still slow - generating a shuffling for example involves a lot of hashing and ends up being costly with no good way to reduce

author: arnetheduck
content: I would point out one specific weakness of #2847 however: it behaves well in a stable network where most nodes share their view of the head - it performs a lot worse when the network is already unstable and will thus exacerbate problems in such conditions

author: arnetheduck
content: we can already see effects of validator set growth: more attestations vote for old blocks and reorgs keep going up - I would draw attention to https://github.com/ethereum/consensus-specs/pull/3433 which would help alleviate some of the problems - it would for example shift some time from the latter stages in the processing pipeline to be given to epoch reorgs, block attestation and TX packing and other heavy operations
